briefdescription.para: The true name of the type, as it would be written in C++.
Description of this parameter, if any.
True if this option is an input option (otherwise, it is output).
If this is an input parameter that needs extra loading, this indicates whether or not it has been loaded.

detaileddescription.para: This is the name used for HasParam() and GetParam().

briefdescription.para: True if this is a matrix that should not be transposed.

detaileddescription.para: Ignored if the parameter is not a matrix.

briefdescription.para: If this should be preserved across different settings (i.e.

detaileddescription.para: if it should exist for every binding), this should be set to true.

briefdescription.para: True if this option is required.

detaileddescription.para: Note that this is TYPENAME() of the user-visible parameter type, not whatever is given by ParameterType<>.

briefdescription.para: The actual value that is held.

detaileddescription.para: If the user has passed a different type, this may be a tuple containing multiple values.

briefdescription.para: True if the option was passed to the program.

detaileddescription.para: Note that wasPassed may be set by either ParseCommandLine() or SetPassed().

briefdescription.para: This structure holds all of the information about a single parameter, including its value (which is set when ParseCommandLine() is called).

detaileddescription.para: It does not hold any information about whether or not it was passedthat is handled elsewhere. A ParamData struct is only useful in order to get "static" information about a parameter. Note that some parameter types have internal types but also different types that are used by CLI11 (specifically, matrix and model types map to strings).
This structure is somewhat unwieldy and is likely to be refactored at some point in the future, but for now it does the job fine.
